review_title: So much potential. So many pompous jerks.
job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Houston, TX
pros: Campus puts a great amount of money into research. Campus works hard to promote the university image. Great medical insurance packages.
cons: Some of the worst politics of any university I have worked. The Provost is unapproachable, full of herself, and downright mean to faculty members who simply want to introduce themselves. I've seen it time and time again. Worst than this, there is major corruption in the leadership of this university on both the college and university levels. Many leaders here will do whatever it takes to protect each other, with an emphasis on protecting people who are liberal. I am ready to find a university to work where employees respect each other, don't talk trash about each other, and actually build each other up instead of tearing each other down. Think that doesn't exist? It actually does. This is for fourth university where I have taught and the ONLY one where adults act this childish. Students are allowed to complain to the deans about faculty for not being fair to them. It's called a syllabus. Some of the teachers in the fine arts wings of the school are unqualified to teach at the university level. It's embarrassing. I would avoid this place and I'm actively looking for a place where faculty are respected by leadership and where faculty respect fellow members.

pros: The quality of the education you will receive is good. Research is well-funded, all things considered. People are friendly, no bad office politics
cons:
Have to pay for parking - UH always has parking problems. You can either pay a lot for a garage pass or skimp on cost and worry about not finding a spot if you get there after 9 AM. 

Have to pay student fees every semester. For some reason you have to pay about 1000/year in fees out of your own pocket as a graduate student instead of the graduate school paying them for you. This is not the case at other schools. Feels confusing to be paid then told to give 1000 back. This is explained as "X department bills you and Y department pays you, and fees are not the same as tuition", but this is not how other graduate programs handle this issue.

Stipends here are on the low end compared to other programs. Also you are not paid your first month but rather starting the second month "because of how the accounting system is set up". I don't remember if you lose a month of pay to this annoyance or if everything is just moved back a month, either way it's unusual. 

Not a top 5, top 10 or top 20 program, but realistically you know this already when weighing your options.

review_title: Honors College Student Services Office Worker Review
job_title: Honors College Student Worker in Houston, TX
pros: I worked as a part-time worker during my time as a student at the UH Honors College. Not only was it an environment where I got to share my excitement about college to prospective students on a daily basis, but it also allowed me to engage with staff and professors on a more professional level when they needed assistance with basic secretarial duties or tasks. I made many phone calls, sent many emails and did a lot to help the image of the college, which was something I pride myself on. It was a great position to have as a first job to any student looking for something part-time on campus.
cons: The environment was stressful and negative at times, and not much concern was shown for the low pay of the student workers. It was easy to feel disrespected at times by the advisors when they had "bad days." Dealing with attitudes while working is never fun. It was still a good experience overall, but the lack of consideration for the feelings of student workers was part of why I left.

review_title: The work is not hard and the pay is decent.
pros: There is plenty of downtime to work around your personal life.  My boss was able to work with me when I had to miss two weeks of work due to a military deployment, which was very nice.  One of the best things is that due to the academic environment, there has never been any overtime.  Most of my work has been project based, so I usually have a deadline for when work needs to be completed, but there is very little micro management of my day to day efforts.  Overall this is a relatively low stress environment to work in.
cons: Overall the work has been boring and the job is not challenging.  The main problem is that there is no room for growth.  The position is treated as an aid, meaning that the work done is entirely based on who you are assigned to.  Some Teaching Assistants work 5 hours a week while others work 20, yet they all get the same stipend.  Some get to do things that will later lead to enhanced career opportunities, while others just do busywork that professors rather not do themselves.  This is obviously a specific problem with this position and not the employer in general.

pros: Some of the Colleges have capable Deans and Associate Deans. The University is starting to be achieve Tier One status on some levels. Tremendous amount of funding has been provided to develop a top ranked football and basketball program.
cons: The University has done little to support initiatives to achieve national or international status in most of the colleges. The College of Liberal Arts & Social Sciences for years has been the problem child of the University. Poor selection of recent Deans have causes financial problems. Recent audits have shown the College to be underfunded and carrying a $6M debt. No vision or strategic plan has been articulated for the past 8+ years. Attempts to develop a new College of the Arts started some 8 years ago with a UH Arts initiatives have been mired hampered by the lack of expertise or vision to develop a comprehensive plan

review_title: Work at the University of Houston doesn't pay well but it does have its benefits.
pros: If you are a student at the University of Houston it is not a terrible place to work. Before and after classes you can walk to your job and sometimes even study when there is no work to be done. The benefits of working as an office assistant there are great. You will have priority registration in most cases, and be put on many different University of Houston listservs so you always know what is going on around campus. Other perks are unlimited printing and color copying and sometimes even a key to the office you work in. You will have access to more information and resources than most other students.
cons: The downside of working on campus is the pay and limited hours. The pay in 2008 never exceeded $9 an hour for anyone and most jobs had a cap on the number of hours you could actually work. Also, your supervisor/advisor/boss may require you to finish some projects or work that will take well over the maximum work hours per week. So you could be working for free a lot of the time to meet deadlines.

review_title: Better than being unemployed, frustrating bureaucracy and petty infighting
job_title: Systems Analyst II in Houston, TX
pros:
Fair amount of time off(esp the free week off between Christmas and New Years)
Nice campus
Laid back atmosphere
cons:
Payscales are horribly outdated.
Higher level mgmt engage in turf wars/feuds down college/dept lines.

review_title: Faculty member in a small department (Central Campus).
pros: The great diversity of students, faculty and staff creates an exciting and stimulating work environment.  The campus is beautiful and the ongoing construction promises a better work environment for many.  The old buildings have character which evokes the image of "hallowed halls" of academia. The classroom work schedule is wonderful and allows time for faculty to work on research.  Positive work/life balance.
cons: It is has been said that incompetence is promoted at UH.  This may be a good thing because it takes these people out of the classroom.  I recall pockets of anarchy in a certain college where antiquated chairpersons and associate deans run slipshod over everyone under their command, except a few favorites.

review_title: very nice campus and other people in the university system
pros: This is a very nice campus atmosphere and a lot of very nice people in the University.  Close to Downtown Houston.  Good if you are working at the main campus.  You have the ability to use some of the facilities since you will be a staff member.  The university setting is a challenging place to work since you will always be encountering  people of high intelligence who will inspire and challenge you.
cons: Con if you are working at main campus is the traffic getting there...  It's in Houston - 4th largest city in US. Anyhow, Getting around campus might be a con if you have to go to different buildings during the day.  It's been a long time since I worked there and can't say too much negative about the University of Houston.

review_title: Student Shelving Assistant at M.D. Anderson Library
pros: Working as a shelver was easy going. I think it was a good opportunity to learn about the day-to-day functions and processes of an academic library. You can listen to music on earphones while you shelve, as long as you are present and doing your duties, which include shelving books, shifting, and shelf-reading according to the Library of Congress Classification.
cons: If you are a woman of color, it is, unfortunately, a very pale and male workplace. Be prepared for microaggressions, feeling talked down to, and just being relegated to menial tasks for menial pay. $8.50 hr/ with a max of twenty hours as a student worker is not okay. Even though the job is generally relaxed, sometimes tasks involving lifting furniture or shelves and it can be straining. There is also a lot of dust in the stacks.

pros: It's a nice university, good location.
cons: Poor salary for adjunct lecturers. Surprised to read here that the Research or Teaching Assistants (offered to students of the university) making double the amount per month compared to adjunct Lecturers ( PhDs)...

review_title: Research at U of H, choose the lab wisely
pros:
Surrounded by smart people if you are in the right research group.
Decent salary. Most research assistants have the same salary so there is not much to complain about.
Decent benefit. Even if you are working part time, you can still get some medical, dental coverage which helps you focus on your research.
cons:
Location is not on the good part of town. Near the ghetto area which the university should annex to expand.
Hard to find smart people outside of lab environment. Most students care less about what they learn and just try to get through. This doesn't count the students from Bauer Business School and other professional schools.

pros: Work for a great cause.  Be part of something bigger than yourself.  Help others and get paid for it.  Go to school easily while working full-time.  One of the most diverse places in Texas.  Help change the world.  Be around very smart people.
cons: Bureaucracy!  Like nothing you've ever imagined.  Lots of politics, petty power struggles.  Some favoritism.  Some good-ole-boy networks.  It is cutting edge in many ways, but in many other ways it's like the US postal service.  Slow to change.  Slow career progression.  Low salary and benefits compared to private sector but in-line with other public sector offerings.

review_title: Great work atmosphere, lousy talent management.
pros:
The time off benefits are probably one of the best reasons to work for U of H.  It takes little time at all to begin earning 3 weeks per year vacation (even though it is accrued by the month).  Also the University closes for a week or so at Christmas.  

The campus community is enjoyable and being in the academic atmosphere is nice as well.
cons: Very little recognition of work and no clear opportunities for advancement.  Human resources and other business groups seem to feel that raises should not be given for high performance and that employees should be made to jump through hoops to get a promotion, even if they have been doing the work for some time.

review_title: A great place for doing science.
pros: Its a great place for doing science in a multi-cultural environment. UofH offers research opportunities in all fields, especially in biomedical areas - that is due to the Texas Medical Center. The benefits are quite good.
cons: Little to no possibilities for advancement and promotion. The organizational structure is flat. Scientist are not given the opportunity for independent research, i.e. only faculty have PI rights. Its kind of a binary deal, either one is hired as faculty and or as a researcher with little ways to advance.

review_title: Overall a good stepping stone to better things
pros: It has a relatively flexible schedule as well as plenty of opportunities to work elsewhere thrown your way. Additionally they seem to care about your development in academia or professionally should you choose to seek private sector employment. They also have up to date equipment available for scientific research in computer science topics.
cons: There is basically no benefits package and the pay is awful. You cannot survive on the pay they give you alone. You basically need to be a student getting student loans or have some wealthier-than-you benefactor helping you through it. Also, the expectations of you are very high by upper principal investigators, though its probably for your own good.

pros: Good benefits, friendly environment, and an aesthetically pleasing campus are the main highlights of UH.
cons: Location in the city, although central, is not the safest albeit not the most dangerous. Nobody should be alone at night on campus or the apartment complexes within close proximity to campus. Antiquated promotion system, inconsistent leadership at the top with visions that different from those actually implementing plans. Virtually no school pride, although it is better than in the 80's and 90's.

pros: The University culture is great if you want flexibility, especially for employees who have familes. 10 days off paid during christmas plus accruing 1 day for every month worked is not bad.
cons: If you want to work in an environment where things do not go through the system like molasses or have to deal with 10 levels of bureacracy, then this is not for you.  Also, their is a very blatant culture of hierarchy between faculty and staff and no ecxuses are made for it.  The staff is treated by most faculty as servants and there is no accountability for faculty in most departments.  Renu Khator also has a dictator style of leading.

review_title: Work at University of Houston not a bad place to be
pros: The working hours are relaxed, no such check in checkout. Since its a college a lot of things are in vertical hierarchy which can be good and which can be bad at times . You get a chance to do work of your own while working at university of Houston , yes that's true you get plenty of time to work of your own. Its a state university so benefits are usually associated with it, the more you stay here the more you would earn . From the very beginning, application to attending class, there has always been great communication.  I can either call, email, or go to the college and someone is available to help ..
cons: Educational college no growth career wise

pros: Gain teaching experiences in traditional face-to-face classroom setting and instructional technology, good side job if you teach distant education classes, ability to teach relatively large range of subjects as long as you have a PhD in the discipline. Adjuncts are less affected by the politics at the workplace
cons: need a PhD to teach as an adjunct, large classroom setting, parking space is very limited, and may have to come to school early if you teach sometime between 9-2 depending on the parking pass you have. Gated parking does have vacant spots, however it is not worth spending over 300 for the academic year if you only teach once or twice a week. Garage and visitor parking can get full especially the first few weeks of the semester. Safety issue especially if you teach evening/night class.

review_title: Started from the Bottom Now I'm in the Middle
pros: Depending on the department you work in there is a lot of flexibility. If you are in school while trying to work this is a great place to work because they are very understanding and will allow you a certain amount of hours to handle school business. People are very kind and helpful. Everyone looks out for each other.
cons: I have never been fond of paying to park where I work. The prices continue to increase. An increase in pay is rarely seen and promotions are rare.

review_title: Hardest workers are taken for granted
pros: Casual work environment. Winter break is pretty decent for a university.  Staff in the trenches are very supportive of each other.
cons: Instead of hiring more staff, salaried staff get overworked with no thoughts from upper management about fair compensation.  Management has no problem with adding duties and expecting staff to work extra long hours.  Politics and favoritism is the norm.  Pay is low and raises are nonexistent for the staff who actually do the work.  Not easy to move between departments and advance.  Turnover is particularly high and nothing is done about it.

review_title: For a PhD student I think the experience is pretty average
job_title: PhD Seeking Student in Houston, TX
pros:
You get paid to learn and increase your human capital. The pay is enough to live on, though you struggle during certain months.

The teaching is hit-or-miss. Some professors will give you a great deal of useful information. Some don't ever show up to class. Some do show up but you can't understand a word they are saying (or writing for that matter).
cons: The pay isn't really indexed to inflation. We got lucky to see one increase in pay due to grad students protesting across the university. It is also the case that you get paid less in the summer which they won't tell you.

pros: Great place to work with great people all around. Great goals for the University as a whole and a place that tries to look out for its own. Great opportunities for growth for those with the talent who are recognized. Many of these are dependent on where you work. In many areas, these opportunities aren't available but that's all dependent on where you work and where I work this is all accurate.
cons: In a previous position, I didn't have really any of the great opportunities that I have now. In my prior position, I was working crazy hours for significantly less pay than what others in my same office were getting. Overall pay can be a little low for mid level management.

review_title: A mediocre institution when I was there in 1980's but it might have improved now.
job_title: Technical Services Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: It has been serving a lot of students in the Southern region who could not afford to go to educational institutions with high flying name.
cons: There were no renowned faculty in any department of this university at that time, and much less any research activity worth its name. Extra curricular cultural activities were almost nil. The ambience of the University is dull.

job_title: Research Assistant in East Houston, TX
pros:
Awesome CIty, great student body, incredible diversity, decent teachers (some are the best, others could improve), constantly changing campus.

While I was there, UH was in a transitional period, and trying to make it out of their "commuter school" reputation. By the last year I was there, 2016, the amount of improvement was obvious.  Much better facilities, tons more staff, more student involvement, best football and baseball teams, and a shift in focus from mostly academic studies to things that were more valued in the work force.
cons: Lack of advisers in MechE, focus on things that are not useful in the work place. Large focus on GPA, minimal focus on co-ops, internships, campus involvement, leadership positions.

pros: Not bad pay. Better than Texas A&M where I made $1650 doing the same thing. Very helpful tips from lab coordinators.
cons: The Physics department has a very strict approach how their labs Must be taught. I was not a fan, but I can imagine that orchestrating so many classes is not an easy task. They could trust more in that we are rather intelligent adults. Expect 2 or 3 weekly assignments per students (~24 students per class) to grade. You will get loaded with homeworks as well. Find a good rhythm and stay on top of everything.

pros:
It is motivating to work in this big campus because you can feel the importance of the mission of the institution which is education and research, and which has the ambition of being Tier One.
My department and lab are dynamic, and composed of good folks, and it creates a favorable place to work hard.
cons:
It can be difficult for labs working in life science because technical cores are not all top equipped or with properly trained and available staff to help users. 
However, the University is changing this, with the construction completed in 2012 of a Health and Biomedical Research Building and the ongoing construction of a Multi-Disciplinary Research & Engineering Building scheduled to be open in 2016.

pros: The pros of working for the University of Houston is the ability to grow and create from your current posistion. The benefits are good, and the paid time off is awesome.
cons: The cons of working for the University of Houston are not a lot of room for growth in department. Work a lot of the time is passed on to other employees without any real justification of why.

pros: Great for working while going to school by letting you take classes and can even get a scholarship to help pay tuition.  Good medical Insurance that pays 100% for the employee and good retirement plan.  Easy atmosphere to work in.
cons: Many bureaucratic red tape.   Like with any government establishment they have to meetings on meetings just to get something done.  I've seen many instances where small problems turn into epic dilemmas because I guess middle management needs to feel like they are doing something.  They also have a tendency to change systems and way of doing things around just so some manager can say he did something.

pros:
Some areas provide a strong work/life balance.
It's certainly a school on the rise, and it's gaining a much better regional reputation.
Comp and benefits are about standard in the field.
cons: UH is dedicated on rising to the upper ranks of colleges in the US, but it's not really putting any effort into a meaningful infrastructure for those changes.  Upper administration issues new fiats on a regular basis with the expectation being everyone shift priorities to follow the new moves.  Ground level employees won't notice as much, but as you move up, expect to see more and more headaches and frustration.  You'll barely have the prior policies implemented before new ones come in.

pros: The job can be fulfilling. Great coworkers, good amount of freedom, management doesn't bother you, can be creative, can make a difference in students' lives
cons: Low pay with no raises in years and no likely raise anytime soon, very hard work, lots of red tape, have to do extra work to get "points" that will count in your favor should layoffs happen, unless you have a wealthy partner, you'll likely have to get a second job to afford living anywhere near campus

pros: The lower division classes have some truly passionate professors dedicated to teaching students. Some students do stick and really do want to learn as much as they can about their classes and at the end of the day, they make the job really worth it.
cons: The department does seem really lax at times, considering few options and resources for the best possible education for the students. Also the basic foundations of the course I taught seemed non-existent as it was left up to undergraduate TA's to plan all assignments and projects from scratch.

review_title: Great part time position for busy person
pros:
My co-workers and management were very understanding of my busy schedule and were able to work around it.
They were helpful when I needed help creating new ideas. There was always a helpful person to answer any questions I had. Their computer technical department was wonderful.
cons: Due to regulation there was low compensation. I believe they had a good benefits program, but I did not use it

review_title: Life as a graduate student at University of Houston
pros: It has multicultural diversity, there are many student organizations. There is really not much pros I can think about other than this.
cons: I am very dissatisfied with the general ambiance of the University. It has been a construction zone for the last 2 years. Not enough budget for departments, assistants dont get paid well enough to maintain decent life standards. Not enough research opportunities for social science students. Very nice physicians at the health center but no specialty doctors are present.

pros: It is a structured educational experience which incorporates a productive work experience as a regular part of a college student's curriculum that involves the student working in a professional setting under the supervision and monitoring of practicing professionals. See student and employer advantages of internships document to learn more
cons: opelessly bureaucratic, all the money goes to the business school, and the liberal arts buildings are lucky to get unlocked bathrooms and working coke machines. It's also in a crap part of town if you go to central, surrounded by ghetto, unlike the awesome Rice campus, surrounded by West U, cool shopping and museum districts, bars, clubs, etc.

pros: Staff at UH are very friendly. As a graduate research assistant I like my job at UH and I believe I will have lot more opportunists. The campus is beautiful. Food options are very diverse.
cons: The main problem with UH campus is neighborhood. It's located near scott street and there are several instances of rubbery at campus. The other problem is about parking. UH has large number of students and staff but there is not enough parking spots available.

pros: One of UH's strengths is its diversity, it is an almost even split between black, white, asian and hispanic students and faculty.  I enjoyed working with international students from different countries. People are generally friendly and hard-working. The University has very good facilities. The city of Houston is great and offers many entertainment opportunities for your spare time. As an employee, you have the ability to select benefits that may be individualized to meet your needs and those of your dependents.
cons: This school is located in a horrible part of Houston. The neighborhood is extremely poor around campus. The summers are hot and humid.

review_title: It is a good place to work and you can get a scholarship.
pros: Job is not hectic unless there is an exam which is few times in a semester.Scholarship is the best benefit offered by the job. You get to sharpen your math & physics skills (or respective classed that you tutor). You can get CRLA certification.
cons: Micromanagement can be a problem. You have to be patient while tutoring. Adjusting job hours during exams could be very stressful. Working with management people can get difficult because they are sometimes hard to reach.

pros: Professional Yet friendly Environment. Provides Flexible environment for the students to help concentrate on their courses yet also able to do the part time. My employer has been very understanding and at the same time help us follow the processes.
cons: It really depends on what department you are studying.  It is busy to take off during the exam times which is because the undergraduate students would also be having exams at the same time.

pros: Respeful environment for employee , well developed organization and have opportunity for growth. A culture of making improvement and I can see UH will continue to become one of the most competitive higher ed institute.
cons: Instead of adding lots of admin to improve education quality, I see that students actually need more scholarship to help completing their degree.

review_title: Hardest working experienced staff are extremely underpaid and overworked.  Why is that?
pros: Competitive employee and retirement benefits, relaxed environment, opportunity to continue learning in a higher education setting, no corporate-type stresses or struggles, working with young people seeking success keeps you young and seeking success, as well.
cons: The campus experiences much too frequent criminal activity (theft, robbery, assault, rape, etc,.).  A large majority of the staff is not very professional in appearance or demeanor.  Experienced professionals (who have the most to offer) are extremely underpaid.  The university as a whole needs a huge overhaul.  The President seems progressive and insightful but the campus is very divided and divisive (ivory tower vs. peasant mentality-it is rumored the President arrives to work by a chauffeured driver).  Tenured faculty have too much power and not enough current insight regarding initiatives to aggressively and progressively reach full Tier One status within the decade.  UH is on its way but tenured faculty will cause many delays along the way.  Most of the old regime is still at the helm which limits how much can be accomplished while they are still around with old ideals.  UH wants to compete with UT and A&M but you have to start with hiring and paying professional staff with current and innovative ideas what they are worth.  Too much politics and not enough credible politicians!  Houston is considered the energy capital of the world and yet, the university cannot seem to build and maintain industrial relationships to make UH the energy university of the world.  Why is that?

review_title: The Entire World On One Campus
pros:
I love the diversity of the people at UH. You can find so many ethnicities, so many beliefs, so many cultures that it's like you have the whole world on one campus. Wonderful for broadening horizons.  

For employees, the University also allows a flexible work-study arrangement so that employees can pursue new or higher degrees and keep their jobs at the same time.  Naturally, there are typical perks such as discounts on software, memberships for airport parking, and discounted/free tickets to events or places around town. 

What your coworkers are like tends to vary a lot by department, but I had very positive relationships with my colleagues and am still good friends with them.  Similarly, UH has many unique and renowned research centers (sadly, the undergrads are not aware of them!) depending on the department you are affiliated with.  It can be a once-in-a-lifetime chance to work with certain equipment or with certain famous professors.

The Texas Medical Center in Houston (world's largest medical center) is also ripe with research opportunities and collaborations, especially for students/employees in the natural sciences, math, education, and computer/technology fields.
cons:
Everyone knows it, but parking is currently a problem (and has been for some time).  Parking is very affordable compared to other universities, but there is simply a lack of space, even for faculty and staff. This is a stressor that reduces job efficiency and satisfaction, if you are constantly coming to work at 5 or 6 am to ensure nearby parking (or coming at a normal time and fearing tardiness).

Funding for employees who are paid by fellowship also varies wildly by department (and supervisor funds). Speaking only of graduate student employees, it was known that technology grad students were paid 1200-1400 per month, whereas psychology grad students received 1100.  Communications grad students did not have offices, making it difficult to work on campus (options were to work at home or share a study carrel in the library), whereas other students had offices, laboratories, and their own designated computers to work on.

Some continuing ed / employee development courses (like on software and computer/internet literacy) had to be cut.  It's a shame because these were useful courses. I knew people who wanted to attend them but could not if the course times coincided with their own classes or meetings.

review_title: Good way of developing an "in" with a professor
job_title: Legal Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: As a research assistant, you can not only develop a substantial level of expertise in a topic area, but also gain an excellent ally on your side for literal future references. This is all the more important if it's one of the law school's professors particularly well known in the Houston legal community: Prof. Weaver and Prof. Hester come particularly to mind, at least if you're EELS.
cons: Opportunity cost of not spending that time working *in* the law, meaning a part-time clerk job that could potentially lead to future employment.

review_title: Good but not great, bad but not terrible, aloof and generally ineffective management.
pros: UH is raising its profile dramatically on the national stage - in one year it went up 150 spots on the USNWR list (mostly because USNWR is junk, but from an 'exposure' perspective it's a big deal).  If you aren't already working at a "tier 1" University, UH is a great place to be because you're 'ground flooring.'
cons: Most of the 'incumbent' management/faculty/etc have attitudes that pre-date the recent improvements at UH.  They treat their jobs, students, customers, etc. as if they are second-class, and it shows in their performance.  Being exceptional in your job is still viewed at UH as a negative in many areas (the one exception being research).  The core service departments have *very* bad attitudes towards their jobs, so anyone relying on them has a big uphill battle to be fought that in my experience has always involved escalations.  (small example of what I mean:  You call a department to ask for something, but reach the wrong person.  They tell you you've rung up the wrong department, and hang up.  They don't give you the number or transfer you or give you any information about how to work.  This is obviously a microcosm, but it's a good vignette of the 'bad' parts of UH.  There are definitely some departments that aren't like this, and individuals within departments that are exceptions - but be prepared for pushback).

pros: Regardless of the department, every supervisor I have ever had has been very accommodating with my class schedule. They are always willing to work out flexible hours (graveyard shift, weekends...) as long as you take responsibility for your work.
cons: Absolutely no benefits (benefits ineligible). Pay = minimum wage - taxes. Legally, international students can only work on-campus (apart from opt/cpt), so I feel like they should get preference over us (who can work anywhere), especially given our large international population ... but I doubt that happens.

pros: Great potential for growth.Working at either one of the University of Houston campuses will give you a great deal of experience on a short period of time. Experience that can be taken and used anywhere.
cons: Parking is probably the only "con" when it comes to working at the University of Houston. All else is great.

pros: The workers are very friendly, great work environment and it was more of a close knit family than a job, everyone looked out for one another and really enjoyed the group gathering.
cons: There is alot of red tape, many decisions are made on what would be the best interest of the school rather than the students. We are not Tier 1 Yet but cannot wait for the day ithappens.

review_title: Great practice job, A LOT of help from very nice advisors.
job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Houston, TX
pros: I was a student graphic designer at the UH Center for Student Media for the majority of a year. You can only be hired in this section while you're a student at UH, so once I graduated that was it. I walked in one day with no appointment, just a resume & a portfolio and they were happy to sit down with me and look at my work for a possible employment. They liked my stuff, so I was called back and hired on the spot. Easiest employment I've ever thought possible. My "advisor" who's basically your boss at this job but with a lot more focus on your personal growth than just getting your job done, was Ana, and she's the nicest person ever. The environment there was really fun, and the hours were as flexible as you needed them to be. Literally you can say in the morning that you have an unexpected appointment with a teacher and they'll say it's fine not to come in. They believe school comes first. You can even be very tired from very little sleep and they'll say it's alright not to come in that day. Also, most employees come in at least 30 minutes after their start time, which is not necessarily good thing but it's awesome to not be penalized for going to panda express and getting lunch before you come in lol. As a graphic designer there I had a lot of work sometimes and barely any others. I worked mainly on advertisement designs for the student publications and such, but I also sometimes had bigger projects like the UH official student calendar, which was very fun to create.
cons: Sometimes there wasn't much to do, so I had to stick around texting on my phone for hours. It's great that they let you use your phone when there's nothing to do though. The pay is very low, but that's to be expected for a "practice job" where you're learning the industry and having great help from the pros as you work.

review_title: Treated like a number,  no regard for work life balance!
job_title: Financial Accounting Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Excellent, inspirational President Dr. Khatur.
cons: Liars, no professionalism or equality.

pros: Lots of training that will prepare you for any job in the future. Not a lot of flexibility in schedule but the schedules are given a semester in advance so that you can plan life around it.
cons: Depending on where you're placed, you may have a few sleepless nights. Pay is not great but room and board are free for all full time RA's.

pros: The politics are about average for a large urban university.  The central campus has a very, very powerful provost.
cons: The University could use substantially more outside administrative talent.  Too much academic "incest".  For example, the business school hasn't had a dean recruited from the outside in over 30 years.

pros: Benefits are okay, lots of time off vacation/sick days and holidays.  Not a stressful environment. University seems to be on an upswing with new spaces and a renewed community interest.
cons: Salaries are lower than competition and ability for growth is low. Raises don't happen very often. Certain department members are only interested in how many times they are published instead of doing actual work that improves university.

pros: University of Houston is a tier one research university and well positioned to become a recognized athletic program.
cons: The main campus atmosphere includes a lack of transparency, large financial deficits, intimidation and bullying by tenured faculty. Staff follows orders and is expected to take the blame when there is problem because tenured faculty are protected and cannot be fired.

job_title: User Services Specialist in Houston, TX

Benefits are good but insurance premium are rising year after year.

Limited career advancement.
Double standard from management . Lack of clear communication , yet they expect us to have clear communication.

review_title: When you are TA to pay for PhD

No benefits but its a undergrade job so I don't really expect it

Tuition fees for fully funded graduate students still comparatively high than other equivalent institutions, more doctoral fellowship coverage needed;

review_title: Great place for full-time students looking for work.

pros: Good salaries. If you're not in Advancement, employees generally seem pretty happy.
cons:
For context, I worked for Advancement:
located off campus in the Third Ward (dangerous area of Houston). Not many safe, quality places to go eat. Can't walk anywhere (too far and too dangerous). 

But the real problem is leadership. They have hired people as managers with no management experience. And they don't provide any management training. The director i was under was young, never managed anyone, was mean, rude, and unwilling to listen. She canceled meetings, when we DID have meetings she limited what we were allowed to talk about (meaning it had to be planned out in advance so she had time to prepare a response - thus killing any chance to brainstorm or be creative). She yelled at employees, told them to be quiet, even chased one through our office demanding that the employee come back to her. Childish behavior from a child. And leadership supported her. They let her chase off or fire 5 of the 8 people on staff within 11 months. She can't articulate what she wants from her employees, sets unreasonable expectations.... the list goes on and on. Basically, it all comes back to her being mean, rude, unexperienced, and UH is not providing her any training. 

The last straw, however, was when she demanded that I call one of my employees who called in sick, demanding that she come in to work. Because my director believed that the employee was lying. Ummm.... hello legal/ethical issues????

They don't care about employees in Advancement. They just don't. I highly recommend you NOT seek a job at UH in Advancement.

pros: Academic environment, flexible work schedule, good benefits
